message.content: We refer to anatomy references for help. The paresthesias in the posterior forearm suggest involvement of the radial nerve, which primarily innervates extensor muscles of the forearm and wrist. Therefore, loss of wrist extension would be an expected physical examination finding.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The paresthesias along the posterior forearm suggest involvement of the radial nerve. Among the options, only loss of wrist extension is a symptom associated with radial nerve injury.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The paresthesias along the posterior forearms suggest a potential injury to the radial nerve. Loss of wrist extension is a common finding in radial nerve injury, while options A, B, and C are more associated with other nerve injuries.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The paresthesias along the posterior forearms suggest involvement of the radial nerve. Loss of wrist extension is a common physical examination finding in radial nerve palsy. Arm abduction, finger abduction, and forearm flexion/supination are controlled by other nerves.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient reported paresthesias along the posterior forearms, which suggests involvement of the radial nerve. The radial nerve innervates the muscles that perform wrist extension, so loss of wrist extension is the most likely physical examination finding. The other options are not associated with radial nerve involvement.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a possible injury to the radial nerve, which innervates the extensor muscles in the arm and wrist extension. Therefore, the correct answer is loss of wrist extension. Options A, B, and C are innervated by other nerves.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location of the paresthesias along the posterior forearms suggests an ulnar nerve injury, which can result from the positioning during the ACL repair. Loss of wrist extension is a common finding in ulnar nerve injury.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and recent history of ACL repair suggest the possibility of nerve injury, specifically the posterior interosseous nerve. This nerve innervates the extensor muscles of the forearm and wrist, so a loss of wrist extension would be expected. None of the other options are associated with this nerve injury.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location of the paresthesias along the posterior forearms suggests a compression of the radial nerve. The radial nerve mainly innervates the extensor muscles of the forearm and wrist, including wrist extension. Therefore, a loss of wrist extension would be expected as a physical examination finding. Loss of arm abduction, finger abduction, and forearm flexion and supination are associated with different nerves or muscle groups.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The paresthesias along the posterior forearms suggest compression of the posterior interosseous nerve, which is responsible for wrist extension. Therefore, the expected physical examination finding would be loss of wrist extension. The other options are not associated with the posterior interosseous nerve.
